content:
This clash is great but:

I updated the contribution to fix the testcase because
- The validator were very different from the Test in IDE.
- There was no Test in IDE with n greater than 9. So it was impossible to guess that n could be bigger.
Interesting puzzle for shortest/reverse game mode. Well done! :D
Admittedly very simple clash. However I've seen even easier ones, and this one isn't half bad. I also do agree with the reverse gamemode.

I very much like this contribution. And I'll be in a great hurry after this comment (I still have to wrap some gifts)

Statement:
I'd somehow state, that the goal are lined up characters
<< Create a beautiful line with decorative characters.
There are English expressions for such decorative lines such as "fairy lights". But as a non native speaker, I'd have difficulties to understand then in a hurry.

Input
The order of n and c in D does is not the same in the description and the examples. So, here is a description which holds the order:
<< Line 1: Space separated strings D, representing the number n and type of decoration (one character c) that should be lined up.

Output
Line 1: Lined up decorative characters

Game modes:
I think this could also work in reversible mode.

less than 1mn in ocaml ==> not fastest : 
let d = input_line stdin in
let l = String.split_on_char ' ' d in 
List.iter (fun s -> 
    let n =int_of_string (String.sub s 0 (String.length s -1)) in 
    Format.printf "%s" (String.make n s.[String.length s - 1])
    
    ) l

so easy that i did not want to do it with my favourites languages ....
45 seconds in python ... and i hate python

d=raw_input().split()
a=""
for i in d:
 a = a+int(i[:-1])*i[-1:]
print a
Well, Constraint says it can be 99 :)
Yes, but it is not dislayed in Reverse mode :) (nothing displayed except test cases)
We just played it (in reverse mode) and everybody had a 50% score because we all missed that n could be greater than 9 from the examples. It should be better now :)
